_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY 

CALIFORNIA ACCIDENTAL 

RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM

E&J GALLO WINERY - FRESNO

September 2015









    The E & J Gallo Fresno Winery is located at 5610 East Olive Avenue in Fresno, California.  The facility crushes grapes in order to produce wine, distilled spirits, and juice for concentrate.  These products are stored prior to shipment to other Gallo facilities for further processing and distribution.



    The facility operates anhydrous ammonia refrigeration systems to provide product cooling.  Refrigeration systems have storage vessels (receivers) sized to contain all the liquid ammonia in the system, with additional capacity for thermal expansion.



    The ammonia refrigeration system is a closed loop heat transfer system.  Ammonia moves through the system due to pressure differences produced by the compressors.  A brief description of the ammonia refrigeration cycle follows:



Refrigeration cycle follows:



1.    The receiver vessel stores liquid ammonia under pressure.  High pressure liquid ammonia flows from the receiver through liquid lines to the expansion valve, which partitions the pressure and temperature.  Liquid ammonia at reduced pressure and temperature is then piped in to the chiller shell.  

2.    Product is circulated through sealed stainless steel tubing within the chiller shell.  Heat from the warm product transfers through the tubing walls to the cooler refrigerant, causing liquid refrigerant to boil off as low pressure vapor.  The rate of vaporization, and thereby the cooling of product, is determined by the amount of pressure in the chiller as controlled by a back pressure regulator, and suction from the compressors.  

3.    The compressors draw the low pressure vapor from the chiller, compress it into high pressure vapor, and discharge it to the evaporative condenser (cooling tower).

4.    In the evaporative condenser, ammonia vapor flows through tubing which is sprayed with water and located within fan driven air flow to promote

cooling.  The ammonia vapor transfers heat through the tubing walls to the cooling water.  The ammonia condenses back to a liquid which drains by gravity to the receiver vessel.  



In addition to ammonia refrigeration systems, the facility uses anhydrous ammonia to adjust the pH of process water being discharged to the Fresno POTW.



 

The Winery maintains storage vessels of liquid sulfur dioxide used as a stabilizing agent during processing activities.

FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY FOR RMP COVERED PROCESSES



        The following statements apply to the listed regulated substances held in processes covered by the Federal Risk Management Program and/or the California Accidental Release Prevention Program requirements.



Sulfur Dioxide        



In the five year period prior to this submission, there has been one releases of Sulfur Dioxide at E & J Gallo, Fresno that exceed the Federal Reportable Quantity of 500 (August 2010 - August 2015). In addition, there have been no accidents that meet the EPA reporting criteria for the Five-Year Accident History at the facility. Such "accidents" would involve on-site deaths, injuries, or significant damage; or known, off-site deaths, injuries, property damage, or envi

ronmental damage. In addition, there have been no injuries resulting from a Sulfur Dioxide release. 

    E&J Gallo Winery has also experienced two non-reportable releases.  On October 3, 2014 an employee was transporting a cylinder of SO2 when the braided hose got caught on a nearby hose rack, resulting in an estimated release of less than 111 lb.  State OES and Fresno County CUPA were notified.  An on-site refrigeration mechanic was able to contain the release by shutting the main valve.

    On August 31, 2014 and employee was adding SO2 to a product tank when the mechanical seal on the pump failed, releasing juice and SO2, resulting in a loss of about 15 lb.  When the employee noticed the juice coming from the seal, the system was shut down, also stopping the release of SO2.



Ammonia



In the five years prior to this submission, there have been no accidents or releases of ammonia at E & J Gallo Winery, Fresno that exceed the Federal Reportable Quantity of 100 pounds in the past five years (August 2010 - August 2015). In addition, there have been no accidents that meet the EPA reporting criteria for the Five-Year Accident History at the facility. Such "accidents" would involve on-site deaths, injuries, or significant damage; or known, off-site deaths, injuries, property damage, or environmental damage. In addition, there have been no injuries resulting from an ammonia release. 



However there have been three non-reportable incidents in the last five years. On May 16, 2011 a leak occurred from a liquid isolation valve at Chiller 41. Maintenance had been performed on the chiller during the day shift. The chiller was then left locked and tagged out with the isolation valve locked and chained as the maintenance was not complete and the system downstream was open. At approximately 1:55 am the valve started to leak by. Around 2:00 am the leak was detected and the Production Team Lead was notified who then notified the EHS Supervisor. The Fresno Fire Department (Hazmat a

nd CUPA) and California OES were notified. A refrigeration mechanic was also contacted to assist with mitigating the release. The leak was stopped at 3:06 am lasting a total of 71 minutes and releasing approximately 5 pounds of ammonia.

On August 10, 2012, there was a vapor release from a relief valve on Chiller 55.  The system had been under a vacuum while recent work was occurring on the system.  The chiller was being water tested, but the suction valve was still closed.  This resulted in vapor being released from the Pressure Relief Valve.  The system was shut down within approximately 5 minutes, resulting in a loss of about 10 lb.

On October 9, 2014, there was a vapor release from an ammonia hotwell.  The system had leaked product, lowering the pH of the hotwell which called for dosing from the ammonia system.  The automatic valve failed open, causing the hotwell to saturate and began to gas off.  When the leak was detected by a security guard going by, a refrigeration mechanic shut the hand valve on the system, then replaced the automatic valve.  The release lasted for about 15 minutes, resulting in a loss of about 5 lb.

        



TOXIC WORST CASE RELEASE SCENARIO:



        The worst case release scenario was determined in accordance with requirements of the California Accidental Release Prevention Program.  This requires modeling the offsite consequences of a total catastrophic failure of the largest storage vessel, with the entire contents of the vessel dispersing into the air within ten minutes. 



Ammonia



        Ammonia



        For the Fresno facility, the worst case scenario would involve the ammonia storage tank used to adjust the pH of the wastewater.  The modeled scenario involved the entire loss of the contents of the vessel, dispersing into the air within ten minutes. For the Fresno facility; this involves the pH adjustment tank at the City Sewer Sump.





TOXIC ALTERNATIVE RELEASE SCENARIOS



Sulfur Dioxide    



        An alternative release scenario would involv

e the catastrophic loss of the entire contents of one of the one ton cylinders of sulfur dioxide within 10 minutes.   



Ammonia



        An alternative release scenario would involve damage to liquid ammonia piping at a chiller due to contact from motorized equipment operating in the area.  If damage was sufficient to cause a failure, it could occur at a flange due to bolt failure, and result in a 1 inch square opening.  The release of liquid ammonia from the opening could be expelled into the air and onto the surrounding surfaces.  







ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION



        The E & J Gallo Winery employs RETA-trained/certified refrigeration mechanics, supported by engineering staff.  The refrigeration system is maintained through the scheduled implementation of a scheduled preventative maintenance program based upon standard industry practices. Employees required to operate ammonia refrigeration equipment receive training specific to their assigned duties and all operators hold the appropriate RETA certifications.







EMERGENCY RESPONSE



        In the event of a reportable chemical release, notifications will be made to the appropriate agencies including the Fresno County Department of Health Services, the State Office of Emergency Services (as directed by the Fresno County CUPA), and the Federal National Response Center (as appropriate). 



        Gallo management and site representatives will respond to the emergency within their level of training and will partner with public emergency response personnel in mitigating the problem.  





MANAGEMENT OF CHANGE



        The Management of Change Procedure will require evaluation of new construction and modifications to existing ammonia systems to determine the likelihood of an effect on ammonia safety.  Changes expected to have a significant safety effect on quantity, systems, or procedures will be referred to the appropriate Risk Management Program team for further study. 





COMPLIANCE AUDITS



        The facility evaluates co

mpliance with the Risk Management Program (RMP) once every three years, at a minimum, to verify that the procedures and practices complying with the RMP program are adequate and is being followed.  The compliance audits are conducted by at least one person knowledgeable in the process. The compliance audit deficiencies are reviewed by a cross-functional team; plan and timetable for resolution of action items are established.   The Compliance Audit will be maintained by the Corporate Legal Department. Resulting action items from the audits will be maintained at the site EHS office. The last compliance audit was conducted by SCS Tracer Environmental November 11-12, 2014. 





PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY 



PROCESS HAZARD ANALYSIS





Ammonia Refrigeration Systems



The most current process hazard analysis (PHA) update was completed February 22-23, 2011 for the refrigeration ammonia systems and was facilitated by SCS Tracer Environmental.  The PHA was conducted over 2 days and the PHA team was comprised of employees with expertise in the following disciples:  instrumentation, refrigeration maintenance, refrigeration operations, safety and health management with extensively training in PHA methodology and refrigeration systems, and environmental.  



The PHA update addressed the following: 



?    Hazards of the process

?    Engineering and administrative controls applicable to the hazards and their interrelationships such as appropriate application of detection methodologies to provide early warning of releases

?    Consequences of failures of engineering and administrative controls

?    Stationary source site map

?    Human factors

?    Qualitative evaluation of a range of possible safety and health effects of failures of controls

?    Consideration of external events, including seismic events, if applicable.  PHAs completed for other programs where external events were not considered shall be updated to include external events



Approximately 132 man-hours were spent o

n the ammonia PHAs. Approximately 8 recommendations resulting from the PHAs were evaluated and addressed by a Process Safety Management/Risk Management Plan (PSM/RMP) steering committee which included the senior managers on site.   Resolution of the PHA action items included the following documentation:



?    Name of individual assigned action item

?    Description of action to be taken

?    Due Date

?    Documentation associated with actions 

?    Communication of actions to operations, maintenance and other employees who work assignments are in the process 





PHAs are updated every five years; records associated with the PHAs are kept for the life of the process.
